intro: Seseli libanotis subsp. leiocarpum, commonly known as the Lebanon sesame or white sesame, is a flowering plant belonging to the Apiaceae family. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and is native to the Mediterranean region, including parts of Lebanon and Syria. It produces small, dry fruits that contain seeds used in traditional medicine and culinary applications. Due to its habitat preferences, it is often found in dry, sunny environments with well-drained soil.
